comments.html: It was only a matter of time before this market segment would receive more attention. IBM will certainly not be the last one.
comments.name: Reggle

comments.html: How is that new job at VMWare?
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: Agreed.  Yawn.  No OpenFlow?  Ok then.. what about Q-in-Q?  PBB?  I'm ready for something new and different in the vSwitch space...  Nicira is already doing better.
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: Very interesting. While IBM entering the space does give some validation to Cisco's efforts, the timing seems very late. The general feedback that I've been hearing is that VMware's virtual switch has been closing the gap with Cisco and that with each upgrade of vSphere that Cisco is losing customers due to challenges with upgrades (and the solution has always on the expensive side, limiting overall adoption). It makes sense for IBM to be more active in edge-networking, we'll see if it has any impact on slowing its decline in bladeserver market share.
comments.name: Stuart Miniman

comments.html: Yep, spot on.  The Nexus 1000V was always a tough upsell in my experience, and an increasingly capable VMware VDS doesn't make it any easier.
comments.name: Brad Hedlund

comments.html: According to this document: http://bladenetwork.net/userfiles/file/VMReadyFAQ.pdf it's source MAC address snooping (similar to what Force10 is doing) and thus not even in the same universe as EVB.

comments.name: Will

comments.html:
Dear vendors:

Making a vSwitch? Impress me and do something different: PBB, Q-in-Q, or MPLS. Otherwise give up now and adopt OpenFlow and let someone else do the networking like Nicira or Big Switch.

Thanks, bye.

Cloudtoad
comments.name: ccie15672

comments.html:
IEEE 802.1Qbg support is in the IBM Virtual Fabric 10G Switch Module (for BladeCenter H) starting with the 6.9.1 firmware. Check the Application Guide (Chapter 16: Edge Virtual Bridging) at http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=isg3T7000496. VMReady 4.0 is this new Qbg based implementation.

Qbg Support in KVM is achieved with macvtap (e.g. in RHEL >= 6.1) and can be used with the IBM Virtual Fabric 10G Switch Module.

P.S. The IBM Virtual Fabric Mode with Emulex 10GbE VFA (CNA) uses Q-in-Q techniques (check the Virtual Fabric Academy website at http://www.virtualfabric.net).

much more to come 8-)
comments.name: Tom Schwaller
